pr_title: Move mapper validation to the mappers themselves

timeline.message: Move mapper validation to the mappers themselves

timeline.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: Do you think these should be on tests for the mappers you are validating?
timeline.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: They're all for aliases, I'll rename the class to FieldAliasMapperValidationTests - I think it's probably still worth having as a separate class.
replies.author: romseygeek

timeline.bodyText: Probably worth javadoc just because all the mappers are going to have to deal with it.
timeline.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: To me it feels fragile to put these checks in a method that can be overridden. If an implementor forgets to call super.validate(...) then we would forget to enforce these important constraints. Perhaps we could keep this logic in a higher-level (non-pluggable) class instead.
timeline.author: jtibshirani

replies.bodyText: We've done this sort of thing a lot in the aggs framework and it has led to some weird methods, doValidate, innerValidate, doInnerValidate and stuff like that. I really wish there were a clean way to force an overrides to call super. Its not something you can force with checkstyle. At least, I don't think it is.
replies.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: I've made validate final and added a doValidate() subclassable method.
replies.author: romseygeek

replies.bodyText: It makes me sad, but if @jtibshirani prefers it that is ok with me.
replies.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: I do prefer it as it's more robust. Unfortunately I can't see a cleaner way to handle this. Would smoothing over the naming make you a bit less sad, perhaps using validateOptions instead of doValidate?
replies.author: jtibshirani

replies.bodyText:
Would smoothing over the naming make you a bit less sad, perhaps using validateOptions instead of doValidate?

The name doesn't really matter. I'll know in my heart that we're doing it because we can't force subclasses to call the superclass implementation. It's cool. Compromise is a way of life.
replies.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: It would be nice to rework the name DocumentFieldMappers -- it doesn't fit so well now that it contains object mappers, as well as FieldTypeLookup. Maybe something like MappingLookup?
timeline.author: jtibshirani

timeline.bodyText: Instead of storing these data structures again, MapperService could just delegate to mapper to retrieve field types, etc. That would clarify who actually 'owns' this data.
timeline.author: jtibshirani

timeline.bodyText: We can also add an @Override to DataStreamTimestampMapper#validate.
timeline.author: jtibshirani
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -70,6 +70,7 @@ protected MetadataFieldMapper(FieldType fieldType, MappedFieldType mappedFieldTy
      * Called when mapping gets merged. Provides the opportunity to validate other fields a metadata field mapper
      * is supposed to work with before a mapping update is completed.
      */
+    @Override

timeline.bodyText: Small comment, we could expose all these checks as a single method DocumentFieldMappers#checkLimits(IndexSettings settings).
timeline.author: jtibshirani

timeline.bodyText: Instead of recalculating this, could we pass in the metadata field mappers directly from DocumentMapper?
timeline.author: jtibshirani

replies.bodyText: I've changed things slightly so that the constructor takes the field count directly, but also added a static factory method that will build a MappingLookup from a Mapper and Analyzer.  This also means that we can move MapperUtils.collect into a private static method on MappingLookup and remove the MapperUtils enum entirely.
replies.author: romseygeek
